image.altText: Woman's hand holds a credit card in front of a computer

props.synopsis: Online retailer The Iconic has failed to provide basic security measures to verify its customers' payment details when placing an order, putting its 2.1 million customers at risk of being defrauded, cybersecurity experts say

title.children: A basic security failure from The Iconic has put millions of its customers at risk of being defrauded

image.altText: Janet Bowden, Michele Matthews and Lynda Bain, composite image

props.synopsis: Three Tasmania women speak of their anguish and fear after having to wait weeks or, in some cases months, for a mammogram — with the Minister for Women saying she is "really sad" to hear of their plight and the government was "aware of that problem".

title.children: Three women, three different breast cancer outcomes, in 'luck of the draw' Tasmanian mammography system

image.altText: James Marape and members of his government

props.synopsis: Social and political tensions were rising across Papua New Guinea, then police went on strike and the streets ignited with deadly unrest, but the prime minister is claiming it was "political influence" that lit the match.

title.children: When the PNG PM appeared with 26 colleagues by his side, there was a clear message

image.altText: A crowd gathers outside a gate while several people try to break through the gate

props.synopsis: Sixteen people have died in violent riots in Papua New Guinea after some residents took advantage of police being on strike to set shops and businesses alight in the capital. The PM has now declared a state of emergency for 14 days.

title.children: State of emergency declared in Papua New Guinea with defence personnel on standby to stop further violence

image.altText: A group of people sit facing a court in a large, high-ceilinged historical building.

props.synopsis: A continent away from the war in Gaza, South Africa accused Israel of committing genocide against the Palestinians and pleaded with the United Nations’ top court on Thursday to urgently order a halt to the country’s military operation.

title.children: South Africa accuses Israel of committing genocide in Gaza in landmark International Court of Justice case

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers speaks to 7.30 after inflation hits two year low

props.synopsis: The government is happy to declare the inflationary benefits of some of its policies but is tight-lipped about the effect of the stage three tax cuts.

title.children: Will the stage three tax cuts worsen inflation? The government remains tight-lipped

image.altText: An aerial shot of a flooded caravan park

props.synopsis: As Shepparton locals wait anxiously to see how high the Goulburn River will peak, other communities have started the process of recovering from flooding and are calling on tourists to reconsider cancelling any visits.

title.children: Calls for tourism support as floodwaters recede in parts of Victoria and Shepparton residents await peak river level

image.altText: Full photo of Farquharson family grave, taken from one side.

props.synopsis: Robert Farquharson, who killed his three sons, is the first convicted killer or serious criminal to have his rights to control the graves of his children taken away.

title.children: Killers and criminals lose the right to control the graves of family members they have harmed

image.altText: Orange haze obscures Parliament House.

props.synopsis: In the event of another summer dominated by bushfires, are our cities better equipped than they were in 2019?

title.children: Australia choked during the Black Summer bushfires. What happens if the smoke comes back?

image.altText: A man and a woman run across a green oval near sprinklers

props.synopsis: Humidity has been at unbearable levels, with simmering waters and moist winds contributing to the warmth across eastern Australia.

title.children: When can eastern Australia expect relief from its higher-than-normal humidity levels?

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu stands in front of two Israeli flags.

props.synopsis: For decades world leaders have agreed the only way to bring about peace between Israelis and Palestinians is through a two-state solution. So why hasn't it happened?

title.children: What are the one-state and two-state solutions for the Israel-Gaza war?

image.altText: Photos of three skiiers in heavy snow

props.synopsis: Siblings Hannah Sugerman and Oliver Thompson were on the slopes with Ms Sugerman's partner Callum when the trio was hit by the avalanche.

title.children: Australian skiers survive being buried by California avalanche

image.altText: Novak Djokovic hits a shot

props.synopsis: Novak Djokovic has won almost everything he can possibly win in tennis. But 2024 offers one final opportunity to achieve the sport's most elusive and exclusive feat — a golden slam.

title.children: In an Olympic year, Djokovic is eyeing a feat only seen once before. The first step is to win in Melbourne

image.altText: Fast food worker

props.synopsis: The "14 and 9 months" minimum working age is a myth. So at what age can you start work in your state?

title.children: The 14 years and 9 months 'myth'. What really is the minimum working age in Australia?

image.altText: Girls get into Australia Day mood in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is calling on Australians to "boycott Woolworths" after the retailer announced it is not going to stock Australia Day merchandise this year. But experts say the company's decision is the result of a movement that's been occurring for years.

title.children: Dutton wants people to 'boycott Woolworths', but it's not the only company backing away from Australia Day

image.altText: A white ute driving on a road next to a homemade road sign

props.synopsis: The weather bureau is forecasting heavy falls from today across parts of Far North Queensland, where communities are still recovering from last month's floods.

title.children: Fears more heavy rain will hamper flood recovery in Far North Queensland

image.altText: A numbat standing in a sun beam in a cracked hollow log, part of the log is like a veranda over it

props.synopsis: New research shows numbats are overheating in high summer temperatures, and scientists suggest climate change could make things worse.

title.children: Hot days could be too much for Australia's cutest anteater

image.altText: a cricketer in purple uniform is bowling a ball on a cricket field with wickets behind him

props.synopsis: The Hobart Hurricane player's windmill-style bowling is making him a cult hero, so how did this Queensland lawyer end up spinning for the Big Bash League side?

title.children: Paddy Dooley's bowling style is unorthodox, much like his path to professional cricket

image.altText: Amanda Spratt cries at a pres conference.

props.synopsis: Three-time Women's Tour Down Under champion Amanda Spratt has broken down as race organisers revealed plans to honour the late Melissa Hoskins in this year's race.

title.children: Tears for Melissa Hoskins from former teammates ahead of Women's Tour Down Under race

image.altText: a man with grey hair in his 60s holds up a silver trophy shaped like an american football

props.synopsis: The six-time NFL champion coach has agreed to part ways with the Patriots after a series of unsuccessful seasons.

title.children: New England Patriots parting ways with legendary NFL coach Bill Belichick after 24 years

image.altText: A young Black man wear a white shirt, black tie and blue jumper, and stands looking thoughtful.

props.synopsis: For some African migrants to Australia, religion can be an essential part of finding acceptance, support and community.

title.children: Malou uses his faith to help other young African migrants — and he's seen huge transformation

image.altText: A blue button jellyfish on a sandy beach

props.synopsis: Pet owners are being urged to keep a close eye on what their dogs eat and drink after wild weather washed ashore toxic jellyfish and contaminated stormwater.

title.children: Sightings of coin-sized jellyfish that fire venom like a harpoon prompts warning from vets after wild weather

image.altText: A young Nepalese man wearing a purple BBL uniform as well as a gold chain and white watch looks intense on a cricket field.

props.synopsis: The 23-year-old Lamichhane was suspended as Nepal's cricket captain last year and taken into custody after police issued an arrest warrant for him over the assault in 2022.

title.children: Former Nepal cricket captain sentenced to eight years in prison for rape

image.altText: Several burnout cars are outside a large building with windows missing and bits of debris hanging off it.

props.synopsis: The strikes come as both Moscow and Kyiv accuse each other of inflicting dozens of civilian casualties in a sharp escalation of attacks.

title.children: Russian missiles strike hotel in Kharkiv, injuring 13

image.altText: A large intercontinental ballistic missile is lauched vertically  from a truck, with flames from its exhaust hitting the ground.

props.synopsis: Kim Jong Un begins 2024 once again escalating North Korea's threats towards its southern neighbour as it becomes evident the nation has traded missiles with Russia for its war against Ukraine.

title.children: North Korea last tested a nuclear weapon in 2017 but their missile launches have since spiked. An expert explains what they're really testing

image.altText: Composite of a man and a bullet hole in a glass door.

props.synopsis: The man shot dead by police on a street in Nowra yesterday has been identified as 34-year-old Alexander Stuart Pinnock, known to authorities after pleading guilty to offences relating to unqualified legal practice last year.

title.children: Fake lawyer Alexander Pinnock identified as gunman killed by police at Nowra medical centre

image.altText: A young man in a suit outside court.

props.synopsis: A NSW magistrate says climate protesters who stopped coal ships during a blockade of the Port of Newcastle in 2023 acted out of "genuine" concern for the environment.

title.children: 'Valuable contributors to society' escape conviction for blocking world's largest port

image.altText: Man in screengrab behind bars

props.synopsis: The Vladimir Putin foe serving a 19-year sentence on charges of extremism, appears in court from the remote Arctic penal colony where he was sent in December.

title.children: Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny cracks jokes in first appearance since Arctic jail transfer

image.altText: the back of a man with a mask on on  acargo ship

props.synopsis: The vote was 11-0 in favour of the resolution, with Russia, China, Algeria and Mozambique abstaining.

title.children: UN Security Council demands halt to Houthi attacks on Red Sea shipping route

image.altText: An empty beach leads to a heavy industrial area with large smoke plumes

props.synopsis: The chief executive of a peak body says the Kwinana industrial area in Perth's south must undergo drastic change if it is to meet state government emissions targets.

title.children: It's an industrial precinct that contributes $15 billion into WA's economy, but what lies in store for Kwinana?

image.altText: An abandoned house with graffiti

props.synopsis: In an outback town suffering crippling building shortages and an overloaded social housing system, dozens of abandoned properties are like a slap in the face to those in need of a home.

title.children: Abandoned houses too expensive to repair 'a disease' on outback Queensland mining city in housing crisis

image.altText: an aerial photo of a train crash

props.synopsis: Police allege the truck driver involved in the collision was distracted on his phone before the crash that derailed the train and disrupted the freight route in an out of the Top End.

title.children: Truck driver charged over spectacular collision with freight train in NT outback that injured four
